[[Greece]] is a transit and destination country for women and children who are subjected to [[human trafficking]], specifically [[forced prostitution]] and conditions of [[Unfree labour|forced labor]] for men, women, and children. Female sex trafficking victims originate primarily in [[Eastern Europe]] and former [[Eastern bloc|Soviet bloc]] countries. Traffickers use physical, emotional, and sexual abuse for coercion. Greece's [[European Union]] membership, coupled with a shared border with [[Turkey]], means the country sees massive flows of [[illegal immigration|illegal immigrants]] looking to enter the EU. Traffickers also use Greece not only as a destination but a transit stop on the way to [[Western Europe]].<ref name="papadimos">Papanicolaou, Georgios. "The Sex Industry, Human Trafficking and the Global Prohibition Regime: A Cautionary Tale from Greece." Trends in Organized Crime 11.4 (2008): 379-409. Springer. Web. 19 Sept. 2012. <http://www.springerlink.com/content/508lh06x47238413/>.</ref>
The [[Politics of Greece|Government of Greece]] does not fully comply with the minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking. The government made clear progress in prosecuting labor and sex trafficking offenses, identifying victims, implementing a child victim protection agreement with [[Albania]], and advancing prevention activities. Concerns remain about trafficking-related police complicity, inadequate victim identification among the [[Hellenic Coast Guard]], border police, and vice police, as well as inadequate funding for anti-trafficking NGOs.<ref name=dos>"Greece". [https://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2010/142760.htm ''Trafficking in Persons Report 2010'']. [[U.S. Department of State]] (June 14, 2010). {{PD-notice}}</ref> The [[European sovereign-debt crisis|economic crisis]] in Greece also places strains on allocation of funding and resources towards anti-trafficking efforts.<ref name="papadimos" />
U.S. State Department's [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] placed the country in [[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|"Tier 2"]] in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/2017/271117.htm|title=Trafficking in Persons Report 2017: Tier Placements|website=www.state.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-01}}</ref>
==Overview of human trafficking== {{main|Human trafficking}}
The [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] (UNODC) defines [[human trafficking]] as "the recruitment, transport, transfer, harboring or receipt of a person by such means as threat or use of force or other forms of coercion, of abduction, of fraud or deception for the purpose of exploitation." <ref name="UNODC">UNODC (2012). Human Trafficking FAQs. Retrieved March 26, 2012, from http://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/human-trafficking/faqs.html</ref> All of the world’s countries are affected by human trafficking, either as a source, destination, or transit country, or a combination of the three. According to the [[International Labour Organization]], an estimated 2.4 million people are victims of trafficking at any given time.<ref>ILO Trafficking in persons (2009). Retrieved February 20, 2012, from http://www.ilo.org/public/</ref> Global trade in women is estimated to be worth between 7 and 12 billion dollars annually; the chair of the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe]] (OSCE) stated that human trafficking may even have overtaken [[illegal drug trade|drug trafficking]] as a lucrative criminal enterprise.<ref name="hughes">Hughes, Donna M. "The "Natasha" Trade: The Transnational Shadow Market of Trafficking in Women." Journal of International Affairs 52.2 (2000): 625-51. Print.</ref><ref name="konrad">Konrad, Helga. "Trafficking in Human Beings: The Ugly Face of Europe." Helsinki Monitor 13.3 (2002): 260-71. Print.</ref>
As of 2010, an estimated 270,000 people are trafficking annually in [[Europe]], with 40,000 women and children aged 12–25 trafficked annually to [[Greece]], as well as an even larger number that are trafficked through Greece to the rest of the [[European Union]].<ref name="kim">Kim, Jeong-Yeoul. The EU's Fight against Trafficking in Human Beings for the Purpose of Sexual Exploitation: Recent Legislation and Measures, and Focal Points Requiring Attention. Diss. Masaryk University, 2010. N.p.: n.p., n.d. Print.</ref> Foreign men are also trafficked into Greece for purposes of sex work but their numbers are largely unknown.<ref name="lazaridis">Lazaridis, Gabriella. "Trafficking and Prostitution: The Growing Exploitation of Migrant Women in Greece." European Journal of Women's Studies 8.1 (2001): 67-102. Print.</ref>
==Destinations==
===Greece as destination=== According to the 2001 [[Greek census 2011|Greek census]], there were 797,091 documented foreigners living in Greece, with a large number from [[Albania]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], and the [[Ukraine]].<ref name="anton">Antonopoulos, Georgios A. "'Are the 'Others' Coming?': Evidence on 'Alien Conspiracy' from Three Illegal Markets in Greece." Crime, Law, and Social Change 52.5 (2009): 475-93. Springer. Web. 19 Sept. 2012. http://www.springerlink.com/content/c834m745566710wv/.</ref> Ten years before that, the number of legal immigrants was only 30,000.<ref name="sitar">Sitaropoulos, Nikolaos, Immigration Law and Management in Greece: Towards an Exodus from Underdevelopment and a Comprehensive Immigration Policy (December 5, 2002). Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1950049 or {{DOI|10.2139/ssrn.1950049}}</ref> By 2009, the immigrant population had expanded to 1.2 million in a country of just of 11 million citizens—legal immigrants make up more than 10% of the Greek population, and the number of [[illegal immigration in Greece|illegal immigrants]] increases the percentage of immigrants even more.<ref name="papadimos" /> The exponential increase in [[immigration to Greece|migration to Greece]] serves as a cover for traffickers, and facilitates their transportation of women for work in the [[sex industry]] in Greece.<ref name="hughes" /> Because of the ease with which traffickers can disguise foreign victims among the immigrant population, Greeks are not typically the targeted victims of traffickers; instead women are brought in from outside the country to fuel the sex industry.<ref name="papadimos" /> Women are brought to Greece from a variety of places, but a large number come from [[Eastern Europe]]—a full 50–55% of sex workers in [[Athens]] are from former [[Eastern Bloc|Soviet bloc]] countries.<ref name="karak">{{cite journal | last1 = Karakatsanis | first1 = Neovi M. | last2 = Swarts | first2 = Jonathan | year = 2003 | title = Migrant Women, Domestic Work and the Sex Trade in Greece: A Snapshot of Migrant Policy in the Making | url = | journal = Greek Review of Social Research | volume = 110 | issue = | pages = 239–70 | doi=10.12681/grsr.9174}}</ref> Greece is also a destination country for a large number of trafficked [[Moldova|Moldavians]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tavcer | first1 = D. Scharie | year = 2006 | title = The Trafficking of Women for Sexual Exploitation: The Situation from the Republic of Moldova to Western Europe | url = | journal = Police Practice and Research | volume = 7 | issue = 2| pages = 135–47 | doi=10.1080/15614260600676817}}</ref>
===Gateway to the European Union=== A large number of trafficked persons are trafficked through Greece on their way to [[Italy]] or other [[Western Europe|Western]] countries.<ref name="papadimos" /> From the 1970s onwards, migrants from [[Asia]] and [[Africa]] began to enter Greece as a temporary stop on their way to other, more developed Western European countries.<ref name="sitar" /> Since then, [[Immigration to Greece|immigration into Greece]], legally and [[Illegal immigration in Greece|illegally]], in order to gain access to the rest of the [[European Union]] has increased, and traffickers have taken advantage of this as well. There are two main trafficking routes that go through Greece in order to reach the European Union. The first is the Balkan Route, through which victims are moved from the [[Balkans]] into [[Slovenia]], [[Hungary]], [[Italy]], and [[Greece]], and from there to the rest of the EU. The second is the Eastern Mediterranean Route, which moves victims from [[Turkey]] through Greece into [[Bulgaria]] and [[Romania]].<ref name="papadimos" /><ref name="konrad" /><ref name="kim" /> Some accounts have estimated that Greece’s border with Turkey serves as the “back-door” entry point for close to 90% of the illegal immigrants to the European Union, and this number includes those transported illegally for purposes of sexual exploitation.<ref name="levers">Levers, Lisa L., and Debra Hyatt-Burkhart. "Immigration Reform and the Potential for Psychosocial Trauma: The Missing Link of Lived Human Experience." Analyses of Social Issues and Public Policy 00.00 (2011): 1-10. Print.</ref>
==Victims== Experts struggle to profile [[human trafficking]] victims because they come from a wide variety of countries and backgrounds and experience different forms of economic and sexual exploitation and abuse. There are certain characteristics that many victims in Greece share, and they face similar challenges and dangers even after being rescued.<ref name="hayle">{{cite journal | last1 = Hoyle | first1 = Carolyn | last2 = Bosworth | first2 = Mary | last3 = Dempsey | first3 = Michelle | year = 2011 | title = Labeling the Victims of Sex Trafficking: Exploring the Borderland between Rhetoric and Reality | url = | journal = [[Social & Legal Studies]] | volume = 20 | issue = 3| pages = 313–29 | doi=10.1177/0964663911405394}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Breuil | first1 = | last2 = Carina Oude | first2 = Brenda | last3 = Siegel | first3 = Dina | last4 = Von Reenen | first4 = Piet | last5 = Beijer | first5 = Annemarieke | last6 = Roos | first6 = Linda | year = 2011 | title = Human Trafficking Revisited: Legal, Enforcement and Ethnographic Narratives on Sex Trafficking to Western Europe | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/v631u7x072024xx1/ | journal = Trends in Organized Crime | volume = 14 | issue = 1| pages = 30–46 | doi=10.1007/s12117-011-9118-0}}</ref>
===Characteristics=== Over 60% of all migrants to Greece, legal and illegal, are female, and over 20,000 migrant women are trafficked annually to work in Greece.<ref name="konrad" /> Approximately 40,000 women and children aged 12–25 are trafficked each year in Greece.<ref name="papadimos" /> The majority of these women today are from [[Eastern Europe]]an and [[Balkans|Balkan]] countries, such as [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Slovakia]], [[Albania]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]], and [[Moldavia]], but there are a fair number from Asia and Africa as well.<ref name="emke">Emke-Poulopoulos, Ira. "Trafficking in Women and Children: Greece, a Country of Destination and Transit." Mediterranean Migration Observatory (2001): n. pag. Print.</ref> More than half the women trafficked in Greece are estimated to be from [[Russia]] and the [[Ukraine]] alone.<ref name="monzini">Monzini, Paola. "Trafficking in Women and Girls and the Involvement of Organised Crime, with Reference to the Situation in Central and Eastern Europe."International Review of Victimology 11.1 (2004): 73-88. Print.</ref> One study from 2001 estimates that 75% of trafficked women in Greece are brought into the country under false pretenses and, believing that an opportunity for lawful employment awaits them in Greece, suddenly find themselves sold to those involved in the [[sex trade]] and threatened with violence and deportation if they refuse to cooperate, and they become too frightened to report it.<ref name="lazaridis" /><ref name="karak" /> The average age of a sex worker in Greece is also lowering, and currently sits at about 12–15 years of age.<ref name="karak" /><ref name="emke" /> Trafficked women work anywhere from 6 to 12 hours a day and see anywhere from 40-110 clients a day.<ref name="lazaridis" /><ref name="emke" /> 70% or more of their earnings, however, go to the brothel owners or pimps in order to keep the women in [[debt bondage]].<ref name="emke" /> Trafficked women are likely to face [[physical abuse]], threats, intimidation, [[psychological abuse|emotional abuse]], [[sexual abuse]], and to experience [[drug addiction|drug]] and [[alcoholism|alcohol addiction]], injuries resulting from violence, and various mental health problems as a result of the trauma they are exposed to.<ref name="hughes" /><ref name="kim" /> Women who are victims of trafficking also often suffer from [[sexually transmitted disease]]s and other [[infectious disease]]s.<ref name="hughes" /> A survey in completed in Athens in the late 1980s found that 12 of 350 registered prostitutes were [[HIV]] positive; in the late 1990s, 44 surveyed foreign prostitutes were HIV positive.<ref name="lazaridis" />
===Challenges after trafficking=== Even after having been freed from entrapping situations, victims may face symptoms consistent with [[Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder]] as a result of the physical, emotional, and sexual trauma to which they were exposed.<ref name="levers"/> Additionally, victims may be stigmatized, marginalized, and discriminated against as a result of their experiences. They often find it difficult to go back to their home countries, where they are no longer considered respectable women, and they find it equally difficult to start a new life in the country into which they have been trafficked.<ref name="lazaridis" /> [[Albania]]n women, for instance, are often stereotyped by Greeks as uneducated, dirty and cheap, but returning to Albania after engaging in prostitution, forced or not, results in shame and loss of honor for the victim's family.<ref name="emke" />
Women freed from trafficking situations face the added danger of a possible return to the [[sex trade]], whether because it is the only life they know or because they are not adequately protected. An estimated 80% of women deported from Greece by train never make it back to their home country because it is common practice for the traffickers to board the trains and force them back to Greece before they reach their destination.<ref name="karak" />
==Traffickers== Traffickers involved in Greece are largely [[Albanians|Albanian]], [[Romanians|Romanian]], and [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]], and while Greeks are infrequent victims of trafficking, Greek citizens do participate in the trafficking of non-Greek nationals.<ref name="papadimos" /> Traffickers recruit victims through false advertisements for low skilled jobs with good salaries, such as waitresses, nannies, dancers, or hostesses; one study of newspapers in [[Ukraine]] showed each newspaper contained 5–20 suspicious adverts.<ref name="hughes" /> Traffickers sometimes use a woman’s legal documents and visas to get her into Greece and then confiscate them so she cannot leave.<ref name="hughes" /> Additionally, traffickers use threats, intimidation, and physical, emotional, and sexual abuse to control these women and force them into prostitution.<ref name="kim" />
==Contributing factors to trafficking==
===Historical factors=== During the 1980s, the majority of foreign prostitutes in Greece originated from [[Asia]], specifically [[Thailand]] and the [[Philippines]].<ref name="emke" /> However, after the fall of the [[Soviet Union]], trafficking in women from former [[Eastern bloc|Soviet bloc]] countries rapidly expanded as women looked to improve their social and economic standings by moving West. This meant they could be taken advantage of by traffickers with the promise of a job in Western European countries.<ref name="emke" /> Former Soviet republics such as [[Belarus]], [[Latvia]], [[Russia]], and the [[Ukraine]] have become major sending countries for trafficked women.<ref name="hughes" /> Today, 50-55% of trafficking victims in Athens are from former Soviet bloc countries, and more than half of the women trafficked into Greece overall are estimated to be from [[Russia]] and [[Ukraine]].<ref name="karak" /><ref name="monzini" />
===Political factors=== The political situation in Greece regarding [[immigration to Greece|immigration]], legal and illegal, facilitates the trafficking of women into and through Greece. Greece experienced massive immigration from the [[Balkans|Balkan]] region in the 1980s and from Central and Eastern Europe in general in the 1990s.<ref name="triand">{{cite journal | last1 = Triandafyllidou | first1 = Anna | year = 2009 | title = Greek Immigration Policy at the Turn of the 21st Century. Lack of Political Will or Purposeful Mismanagement? | url = | journal = European Journal of Migration and Law | volume = 11 | issue = | pages = 159–77 | doi=10.1163/157181609x440013}}</ref> By 2009, Greece’s legal immigrant population had expanded to 1.2 million, or 10% of the Greek population.<ref name="triand" /> At the time when these immigration flows were rapidly expanding, the [[Government of Greece|Greek government]] and immigration policies were unprepared to deal with such a large number of immigrants; Greece's ability to deal with the multitudes of illegal immigrants was even less developed.<ref name="triand" /> The challenges Greece has faced with its large immigrant population and implementing successful immigration policy allows migrants that are trafficked and forced into prostitution to slip through the cracks and allows traffickers to hide them among the general migrant population.<ref name="hughes" />
Greece’s European Union membership, coupled with its geographical location between East and West, also contributes to its role as a transit nation in trafficking routes. As a gateway to Western Europe, victims are often trafficked through Greece in order to reach other EU countries.<ref name="papadimos" /> Greece’s border with [[Turkey]] is also a hotspot for illegal immigrants looking to find their way into the European Union; from 1991–2001 over 2.2 million migrants who had entered Greece illegally were deported, and the vast majority of these had arrived in Greece through Turkey.<ref name="sitar" /> In 2001, 6,471 immigrants were apprehended at sea trying to reach Greece from Turkey.<ref name="sitar" /> An estimated 90% of the illegal immigrants to the entire European continent enter the EU through Greece’s border with Turkey; this migration number includes the tens of thousands of trafficking victims.<ref name="levers" /> On January 20, 2000, the Greco-Turkish Agreement was signed. Both countries aimed at “combating crime, especially terrorism, organized crime, illicit drug trafficking and illegal migration” as part of the agreement, in addition to human trafficking between the two countries.<ref name="sitar" />
===Socio-cultural factors=== Strong [[xenophobia|xenophobic]] tendencies in Greece also contribute to trafficking. Various studies and polls continuously report Greece as the most xenophobic country in Europe.<ref name="karak" /> There is a perception among Greeks that foreign ethnicities are involved in [[organized crime]].<ref name="anton" /> Inherent xenophobia in Greece has allowed the trafficking of outsiders; ethnic bias against [[Albanians]] and other foreigners has potentially prohibited Greece from recognizing and properly caring for victims who are not of Greek origin.<ref name="papadimos" />
==Governmental anti-trafficking efforts== There are several international standards for combating [[human trafficking]]. The UN [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children]], also known as the Palermo Protocol, lays down universal, fundamental regulations for international organization and cooperation for combating trafficking. Greece signed the Protocol on December 13, 2000 and proceeded to completing the ratification process on January 11, 2011.<ref>[http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XVIII-12-a&chapter=18&lang=en#EndDec [[UN]] CHAPTER XVIII, PENAL MATTERS, 12 .a Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime]</ref> The [[European Union]] has developed an anti-trafficking response that underpins the ‘3P’s of the Palermo Protocol—prosecution of traffickers, protection of victims, and prevention of trafficking.<ref name="karak" /> Since 2000, the [[United States Department of State|U.S State Department]] has created an analysis of anti-trafficking efforts country by country around the world that ranks each country based on their anti-trafficking efforts, resulting in the annual Trafficking in Persons Report (TIP).<ref name="papadimos" /> From 2001 to 2003, Greece was placed on the Tier 3 list of the TIP report, which means the government was essentially ignoring the human trafficking problem.<ref name="papadimos" /> As the government made strides to address issues of human trafficking, it was moved to the Tier 2 Watch List in 2004, and in 2006 was placed on Tier 2, where it remains as of 2012.<ref name="papadimos" />
===Prosecution=== The government demonstrated clear progress in its prosecution of trafficking offenders, though a high-profile case of trafficking-related complicity remained pending in court as of 2010. Under the Alien Act law 1975/1991, which lasted until June 2001, there were penalties for trafficking human beings but there was no legislation specifically criminalizing trafficking.<ref name="lymouris">Lymouris, Nikolaos (2007), "Trafficking in Greece", Conference Presentation, 3rd PhD Symposium, London School of Economics / Hellenic Observatory, available at http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/hellenicObservatory/pdf/3rd_Symposium/PAPERS/LYMOURIS_NIKOLAOS.pdf</ref> In 2002, Greece passed law 3064/2002, the first Greek law to criminalize human trafficking and outlaw trafficking for sexual and labor exploitation.<ref name="papadimos" /> Police conducted 66 human trafficking investigations in 2009, a 65 percent increase over the 40 investigations in 2008. The government reported 32 new convictions of trafficking offenders in 2009, compared with 21 convictions in 2008.<ref name=dos/> The average sentence for trafficking offenders was approximately 11 years with fines. The [[Minister for Justice, Transparency and Human Rights (Greece)|Ministry of Justice]] reported two suspended sentences in 2009. Some convicted trafficking offenders continued to be granted bail pending their lengthy appeals. The media continues to allege that trafficking-related complicity exists among some local police and vice squad officers. In a case cited in the 2010 TIP Report, a trafficking victim was allegedly raped while in police custody in 2006.<ref name=dos/> In a positive development in 2009, one active and one retired officer were held without bail pending prosecution for alleged involvement in sex trafficking. In 2009, the Greek police reported cooperation with counterparts in [[Albania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Italy]], [[Romania]], and [[Russia]] on trafficking cases.<ref name=dos/> As of 2011, Greece has laws and penalties pertaining to Article 2 of the [[Directive (European Union)|European Directive of 2011]], which states all EU Member States must have legislation that punishes traffickers, regardless of the type of trafficking.<ref name="papadimos" />
===Protection=== The government has demonstrated some progress in ensuring that victims of trafficking were provided access to essential services. Before 2001, a person who made his or her living from [[prostitution]] was liable to prosecution; since then, laws have been implemented that seek to care for the victim and punish the trafficker instead.<ref name="lazaridis" /> In 2000 a Task Force against human trafficking was created to identify and assist victims, and in 2007 the largest trafficking ring known to date in [[Thessaloniki]] was dismantled.<ref name="papadimos" /> In 2003, Presidential Decree 223/2003 introduced measures for the assistance and protection of victims of human trafficking.<ref name="lymouris" /> In August 2004, a National Action Plan was developed to implement a wide variety of counter-trafficking efforts, including collecting facts and statistics, establishing procedures to identify victims, establish shelters, provide victims with legal recourse, and educating police, judges, and other member of law enforcement.<ref name="lymouris" /> The [[Minister for Health and Social Solidarity (Greece)|Ministry of Health]] trained nurses, medical admissions staff, psychologists, psychiatrists, and social workers on the identification of trafficking victims. Similarly, experienced anti-trafficking police continued to provide training to border police, vice police, and the [[Hellenic Coast Guard]] on victim identification. Greece provided officially-identified trafficking victims with access to legal and medical services through government-run shelters, public healthcare, and intermittent funding to NGOs.
In 2005, law 3386/2005 was passed to better assist victims of trafficking; however, victim identification continues to be a weak point of Greek anti-trafficking efforts.<ref name="papadimos" /> The government officially identified only 125 human trafficking victims in 2009, an improvement over the 78 victims identified in 2008.<ref name=dos/> The government continued to operate a short-term shelter, which could accommodate children, in addition to two long-term shelters for women. The government also referred child victims to orphanages or detention centers that did not have specialized facilities for trafficking victims. One NGO reported that authorities released unaccompanied foreign minors onto the street with little support after detention. The government encouraged victims to participate in prosecutions by offering a 30-day reflection period, a time for victims to receive immediate care while they consider whether to assist law enforcement, but according to NGOs, authorities did not always provide the reflection period consistently during the reporting period. Victims who assisted with law enforcement prosecutions qualified for temporary, renewable residence permits as a legal alternative to removal. NGOs reported excellent cooperation with specialized anti-trafficking police units. Overall, the government did not penalize victims for unlawful acts that may have been committed as a direct result of being trafficked. However, some NGOs reported that the coast guard and border police, overwhelmed with processing refugees and undocumented migrants, had little time to use victim identification procedures. As a result, they sent many potential victims, including vulnerable unaccompanied minors, to migrant detention centers, where they often faced poor conditions. In a positive development, the government implemented a child repatriation agreement with [[Albania]], repatriating six Albanian child victims in cooperation with NGOs.<ref name=dos/>
===Prevention=== The government has demonstrated steady progress in the prevention of trafficking. In 2009, a state television station aired a special on human trafficking in Greece in addition to other programs on the topic.<ref name=dos/> The [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] spoke out against trafficking, and since October 2009, anti-trafficking NGOs have reported stronger partnerships with high-level officials. The government, in partnership with [[International Organization for Migration|IOM]] and [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]], provided anti-trafficking training for police recruits and commanders, police from neighboring countries, and over 100 judges and prosecutors. The [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] provided $155,100 toward a [[UNICEF]] campaign on [[trafficking of children]] as a global phenomenon and funded an [[International Organization for Migration]]-produced public awareness campaign acknowledging trafficking as a problem in Greece. The government did not run any new campaigns targeting the clients of prostitution or beneficiaries of forced labor. The government implemented a law enforcement-focused national plan of anti-trafficking action; however, the government lacked a central authority to coordinate ministries’ anti-trafficking efforts and monitor anti-trafficking results. Coordination of data between agencies remained ad hoc. The Greek government facilitated anti-trafficking partnerships by funding initiatives in neighboring countries. Greek law provide extraterritorial jurisdiction over [[child sex tourism]] offenses by its nationals; the government did not report any prosecutions of Greek citizens for child sex tourism during the reporting period. The government gave its peacekeeping troops anti-trafficking training before deploying them abroad. Since 2011, Greece is a party to the 2000 UN TIP Protocol.
==NGO anti-trafficking efforts== In addition to governmental efforts, several [[non-governmental organization]]s, or NGOs, are also making strides to combat trafficking in Greece. NGOs reported that government grant disbursement delays, onerous reporting requirements, and deteriorating public finances have created financial difficulty for trafficking victim service providers dependent on government funding <ref name=dos/> In 2001, StopNow project was launched to raise awareness and lobby public organizations on trafficking issues.<ref name="papadimos"/> The [[List of Greek think tanks|Marangopoulos Foundation for Human Rights]] conducts and analyses research on trafficking in women in Greece.<ref name="lazaridis" /> The [[A21 Campaign]], an NGO founded in 2008, promotes awareness about human trafficking, and rehabilitates and provides legal support to survivors. In 2009 A21 opened a crisis shelter for victims in [[Thessaloniki]] and works with the Greek government to assist trafficking victims.<ref name="papadimos" /> The [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] works closely with the NGO “Smile of a Child” to implement an [[amber alert]] program aimed at helping trafficked missing children.<ref name="lymouris" /> The Greek NGO “KEPAD” (Human Rights Defense Center) works to establish and maintain a network or anti-trafficking NGOs in the Balkan region that work cooperatively to combat trafficking.<ref name="lymouris" /> NGOs, some of whom received government funding, reported assisting at least 3,376 trafficking victims in 2009, significantly more than the 125 victims identified by the government.<ref name=dos/>
==Remaining challenges== As of 2012, the Greek government has made important strides in anti-trafficking efforts by tightening legislation and increasing the services and assistance to victims of trafficking in recent years. However, the current [[Greek government-debt crisis|economic crisis]] in Greece has vastly limited the government’s ability to help trafficking victims; severe economic conditions have taken resources and attention away from the issue of human trafficking. While the country remains in economic crisis, funding to various social services and anti-trafficking efforts will remain low as economic [[bailout]] money is allocated elsewhere.<ref name="papadimos" />

[[File:Addo Elephant National Park-005.jpg|thumb|Signage in [[Addo Elephant National Park]] reminding people of the possible threat lions pose.]] '''Human–lion conflict''' refers to the pattern of problematic interactions between native people and lions. Conflict with humans is a major contributor of the decline in [[lion]] populations in [[Africa]].<ref name=Hazzah2014>{{cite journal | last1 = Hazzah | first1 = L. | last2 = Dolrenry | first2 = S. | last3 = Naughton | first3 = L. | last4 = Edwards | first4 = C.T.T. | last5 = Mwebi | first5 = O. | last6 = Kearney | first6 = F. | last7 = Frank | first7 = L. | year = 2014 | title = Efficacy of two lion conservation programs in Maasailand, Kenya | doi = 10.1111/cobi.1224 | journal = Conservation Biology | volume = 28 | issue = | pages = 851–860 }}</ref> [[Habitat destruction|Habitat loss]] and [[habitat fragmentation|fragmentation]] due to conversion of land for agriculture has forced lions to live in closer proximity to human settlements.<ref name=Abade2014>{{cite journal | last1 = Abade | first1 = L. | last2 = MacDonald | first2 = D.W. | last3 = Dickman | first3 = A.J. | year = 2014 | title = Assessing the relative importance of landscape and husbandry factors in determining large carnivore depredation risk in Tanzania's Ruaha landscape | doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2014.10.005 | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 180 | issue = | pages = 241–248 }}</ref> As a result, conflict is often characterized by lions preying upon [[livestock]], known as livestock depredation. When depredation events take place, farmers suffer financial losses and lions face threats of retaliatory killing.
==Causes of conflict== The main cause of conflict is habitat loss.<ref name=Abade2014 /> 83% of the African lion's range has been reduced and what remains is increasingly fragmented.<ref name=Hazzah2009>{{cite journal | last1 = Hazzah | first1 = L. | last2 = Borgerhoof Mulder | first2 = M. | last3 = Frank | first3 = L. | year = 2009 | title = Lions and warriors: Social factors underlying declining African lion populations and the effect of incentive-based management in Kenya | doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2009.06/006 | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 142 | issue = | pages = 2428–2437 }}</ref> Lions, as large [[carnivore]]s, rely on large connected expanses of land.<ref name=Rosenblatt2014>{{cite journal | last1 = Rosenblatt | first1 = E. | last2 = Becker | first2 = M.S. | last3 = Creel | first3 = S. | last4 = Droge | first4 = E. | last5 = Mweetwa | first5 = T. | last6 = Schuette | first6 = P.A. | last7 = Watson | first7 = F. | last8 = Merkle | first8 = | last9 = Mwape | first9 = H. | year = 2014 | title = Detecting declines of apex carnivores and evaluating their causes: an example with Zambian lions | doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2014.10.006 | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 180 | issue = | pages = 176–186 }}</ref> The conversion of their habitat into agricultural land prevents them from dispersing and can limit the availability of natural prey.<ref name=Schuette2013>{{cite journal | last1 = Schuette | first1 = P. | last2 = Creel | first2 = S. | last3 = Christianson | first3 = D. | year = 2013 | title = Coexistence of African lions, livestock, and people in a landscape with variable human land use and seasonal movements | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 157 | issue = | pages = 148–154 | doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2012.09.011}}</ref><ref name=Bauer2010>{{cite journal | last1 = Bauer | first1 = H. | last2 = de Iongh | first2 = H. | last3 = Sogbohossou | first3 = E. | year = 2010 | title = Assessment and mitigation of human-lion conflict in West and Central Africa | doi = 10.1515/MAMM.2010.048 | journal = Mammalia | volume = 74 | issue = | pages = 363–367 }}</ref> Lions are therefore roaming closer to farms than before and are at a higher risk of preying on livestock.
===Ecological variables=== There are many ecological variables that can affect likelihood of depredation. Factors such as farms' distance from water sources,<ref name=Abade2014 /> [[protected area]]s,<ref name=Schuette2013 /><ref name=Thorn2012>{{cite journal | last1 = Thorn | first1 = M. | last2 = Green | first2 = M. | last3 = Dalerum | first3 = F. | last4 = Bateman | first4 = P.W. | last5 = Scott | first5 = D.M. | year = 2012 | title = What drives human carnivore conflict in the North West province of South Africa? | doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2012.02.017 | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 150 | issue = | pages = 23–32 }}</ref> elevation<ref name=Abade2014 /> and surrounding vegetative cover<ref name =Schuette2013 /><ref name=Thorn2012 /> may all play a role. Some research has shown that depredation decreases with distance from protected areas.<ref name=Thorn2012 /> This could be because access to nearby conservation areas provides lions with a refuge when coming into contact with humans.<ref name=Schuette2013 /> Farms that are located close to water sources and at a low elevation may be especially vulnerable to conflict.<ref name=Abade2014 /> The effect of vegetative cover remains unclear. Dense vegetative cover has been associated with a higher rate of depredation<ref name=Thorn2012 /> yet has also been shown to reduce depredation as it allows predators to hide from humans.<ref name=Schuette2013 /> Farm and livestock management can also affect chances of depredation. [[Pen (enclosure)|Corralling]] livestock at night<ref name=Schuette2013 /> as well as providing guards to monitor lion movements to prevent and deter [[predation]]<ref name=Hazzah2014 /> can limit losses.
==Financial losses== Depredation events lead to financial losses to farmers who rely on livestock as a source of income. In the [[North West (South African province)|North West province]] of [[South Africa]], around $375, 797USD were lost as a result of game and livestock losses caused by depredation.<ref name=Thorn2012 /> It should be noted that lions are not the only predators involved, with [[hyena]]s, [[leopard]]s, and [[Wild Dog|wild dog]]s responsible for depredation events as well.<ref name=Schuette2013 /><ref name=Kissui2008>{{cite journal | last1 = Kissui | first1 = B.M. | year = 2008 | title = Livestock predation by lions, leopards, spotted hyenas, and their vulnerability to retaliatory killing in the Maasai steppe, Tanzania | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-1795.2008.00199.x | journal = Animal Conservation | volume = 11 | issue = | pages = 422–432 }}</ref> However, lions typically attack cattle which incur higher financial losses than sheep and goats (hunted by hyenas and leopards).<ref name=Hazzah2009 /><ref name=Kissui2008 />
===Compensation=== In order to lessen these financial losses, some regions offer financial compensation to affected farmers. However, these programs are not always effective. Major criticisms revolve around the response times of programs, arguing that they take too long or do not happen at all. Additionally, farmers do not always receive sufficient financial restitution. For example, as of 2009, [[Botswana]]'s state-funded compensation program only compensated farmers for 80% of the value they lost. It is common for farmers to not even report livestock losses due in part to dissatisfaction with response time and amount.<ref name=Hemson2009>{{cite journal | last1 = Hemson | first1 = G. | last2 = Maclennan | first2 = S. | last3 = Mills | first3 = G. | last4 = Johnson | first4 = P. | last5 = Macdonald | first5 = D. | year = 2009 | title = Community, lions,livestock and money: a spatial and social analysis of attitudes to wildlife and the conservation value of tourism in a human-carnivore conflict in Botswana | doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2009.06.024 | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 142 | issue = | pages = 2718–2725 }}</ref> However, the Predator Compensation Fund (PCF) in Massailand, [[Kenya]] has reduced retaliatory killings following depredation events by 73%, illustrating that when done correctly, compensation programs can be effective.<ref name=Hazzah2014 /> Farmers who have received compensation have also reported a lower likelihood of killing a suspected lion than those who have not received any.<ref name=Hazzah2009 /> Regardless of their efficacy, compensation programs are reactionary and not preventative, only seeking to mitigate farmers' losses after the event and do not address underlying causes of conflict<ref name=Hazzah2014 />
==Retaliatory killing== Retaliatory killing is the hunting of a suspected predator after a depredation event. While a threat for all predators, lions are killed disproportionately to the number of losses they are responsible for as opposed to [[hyena]]s and [[leopard]]s.<ref name=Hazzah2009 /><ref name=Kissui2008 /> One reason lions are killed in retaliation more than other carnivores is because of their propensity to kill [[cattle]] more than [[sheep]] and [[goats]].<ref name=Hazzah2009 /> Because cattle are of more financial value to farmers than sheep and goats, the desire to retaliate can be greater. Lions also will hunt during the night when most attacks take place,<ref name=Kissui2008 /> are easier to track,<ref name=Hazzah2009 /> and are more likely to defend a carcass which make them more vulnerable to being killed by humans<ref name=Kissui2008 />
===Likelihood of retaliation=== Social and economic differences also impact motivation to [[lion hunting|hunt lions]] in reaction to livestock losses. People who have lost a higher proportion of their livestock to depredation (often those with smaller farms to begin with) as well as those owning livestock for the purpose of sale as opposed to traditional or subsistence reasons have been found to report a higher willingness to retaliate.<ref name=Hazzah2009 /> Both higher proportional losses and keeping livestock for sale increase the value of cattle and therefore increase the financial incentive to kill suspected predators. Likelihood to retaliate has also been shown to be influenced by social factors such as [[religion]]<ref name=Hazzah2009 /> and [[culture]]<ref name=Thorn2012 /><ref name=Kissui2008 />
==Reducing conflict== Due to the complex social, economic, and ecological aspects of human-lion conflict, it is recommended that mitigation strategies be adaptable and situation-specific.<ref name=Hazzah2014 /><ref name=Hazzah2009 /><ref name=Schuette2013 /><ref name=Thorn2012 /><ref name=Kissui2008 /> Specific actions such as providing guards to monitor predators and protect cattle,<ref name=Hazzah2014 /> corralling livestock at night,<ref name=Schuette2013 /> providing compensation<ref name=Hazzah2014 /> and restoring natural prey densities<ref name=Bauer2010 /> may reduce conflict in some areas. Focusing on unique conservation programs that take into account factors such as culture<ref name=Hazzah2014 /><ref name=Thorn2012 /><ref name=Kissui2008 /> and religion,<ref name=Hazzah2009 /> type of livestock owned,<ref name=Hazzah2009 /><ref name=Kissui2008 /> and reason for owning livestock<ref name=Hazzah2009 /> may also be helpful.

[[File:Wassilij Grigorjewitsch Perow 004.jpg|thumb|300px|''The Hunters at Rest'' by [[Vasily Perov]]. 1871.]] '''Hunting in Russia''' has an old tradition in terms of [[List of indigenous peoples of Russia|indigenous people]], while the original features of state and princely economy were farming and cattle-breeding. There was [[hunting]] for food as well as sport. The word "hunting" ("охота", ''okhota'') first appeared in the common [[Russian language]] at the end of the 15th century.<ref name="HNT">{{cite web | last = | first = |authorlink = | coauthors = | script-title=ru:Охота. Период Российского государства| work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://hunt-story.spb.ru/index/rus/| format =| doi = | accessdate = 2007-06-09|language=ru}}</ref> Before that the word "catchings" ("ловы", ''lovy'') existed to designate the hunting business in general.<ref name="HNT"/> The hunting grounds were called in turn ''lovishcha'' ("ловища").<ref name="HNT"/> In the 15th-16th centuries, foreign ambassadors were frequently invited to hunts; they also received some of the prey afterwards. So did [[Feodor I of Russia|Feodor I]] in particular, once sending out nine [[elk]]s, one [[bear]] and a black-and-brown [[fox]].
The right of using the hunting grounds in Russia was once granted to every social class. The right of the nobility was even sometimes limited by agreements with others regarding hunting grounds. The [[falconry|hawkers]] and separate persons who dealt with [[hound]]s, [[beaver]]s, [[black grouse]]s, [[hare]]s, etc. were permitted either on the landed properties, or on territories specified by local people. Though the [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodox]] clergy once disapproved the hunting, these persons were authorized to eat and feed their horses, hounds and falcons on others' account or even demand participation in hunting.<ref>''Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary''</ref>
The Russian imperial hunts evolved from hunting traditions of early Russian rulers ([[Grand Prince]]s and [[Tsar#Russia|Tsar]]s), under the influence of hunting customs of European royal courts. The imperial hunts were organized mainly in [[Peterhof Palace|Peterhof]], [[Tsarskoye Selo]] and [[Gatchina]].
During the soviet rule, state-sponsored hunting clubs were formed within the administrative boundaries or factories. Hunting clubs based in cities were allocated hunting grounds where club members were allowed to hunt according to the federal and local regulations. Following demise of the Soviet Union private individuals were allowed to lease hunting territories formerly used by government sponsored clubs. Many lease owners are wealthy Russians who are willing to spend large sums of money in order to maintain leased hunting grounds for their pleasure and sometimes to allow other hunters to use their territories for a fee. As a result, the quality and quantity of the game increased dramatically during the past 20 years in most parts of Russia.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} During the Soviet Union time, a single agency called "Glavohota" was granted an authority to conduct hunts for the foreign hunters. Nowadays many outfitters and booking agents organize hunting trips for the foreigners. The inevitable competition between such companies improved quality of hunts and brought down the prices which used to be extremely high.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
==Big game==
===Bear=== Russia's northeast part, the [[Kamchatka Peninsula]] and the coastal regions of the [[Pacific Ocean]], have the highest density of [[brown bear]]s. There are [[Eurasian brown bear]] (''Ursus arctos arctos''), [[Siberian brown bear]] (''Ursus arctos beringianus''), [[Syrian brown bear]] (''Ursus arctos syriacus''), [[Ussuri brown bear]] (''Ursus arctos lasiotus''), etc.
[[Grand Prince of Moscow]] [[Ivan IV of Russia|Ivan IV Vasilyevich]] was present at the bear hunts at the age of 13.<ref>Карамзин, Н. М. ''История государства Российского'', т. VIII</ref> [[False Dmitriy I]] was especially keen on bear hunting.<ref>Карамзин, Н. М. ''История государства Российского'', т. XI; Буссов, К. ''Московская хроника. 1584–1613''. М.-Л., 1961., с. 111</ref> A legend describes the miraculous salvation of Tsar [[Alexis of Russia]] from a bear by [[Saint Sava]]. After 1650/51 the bear hunts of Tsars became rare. In 2007 Russia proposed to allow [[polar bear|polar bear hunting]] by the [[Chukchi people]], for the first time since the [[Soviet Union]] banned hunting the dwindling species in 1956.<ref>{{cite news |title=Russia to Allow Subsistence Hunting of Polar Bears |url=http://outside.away.com/outside/news/20070417_01.html |publisher= |first=Christina |last=Erb |date=April 17, 2007 |accessdate=2007-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514094418/http://outside.away.com/outside/news/20070417_01.html |archivedate=May 14, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
=== Wolf === {{main|Wolf hunting}} The wolf is the most widespread large indigenous [[game animal]] in Russia.<ref name="HT">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Wolf Hunting in Russia| work =| publisher =| date =| url =http://www.russianhunting.com/wolf-hunting-in-russia/| format =| doi =| accessdate =2007-06-09| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070531113840/http://www.russianhunting.com/wolf-hunting-in-russia/| archivedate =2007-05-31| df =}}</ref> The best hunting time is considered to be January–February.<ref name="HT"/> [[File:Provedenie meropriyatii po otstrelu vrednyh givotnyh na territorii Kamyshinskogo raiona Volgogradskoi oblasti.jpg|thumb|Carcasses of hunted wolves in [[Kamyshinsky District]], [[Volgograd Oblast]], [[Russia]].]] Wolves were hunted in both [[Russian Empire|Czarist]] and Soviet Russia with [[borzoi]] by landowners and [[Cossack]]s.<ref name="control">''Chapter 10: Wolf Control Methods'' in Will Graves, and Valerius Geist, editors. ''Wolves in Russia''. Detselig Enterprises Ltd. 210, 1220 Kensington Road NW, Calgary, Alberta T2N 3P5. USA.</ref> Covers were drawn by sending mounted men through a wood with a number of dogs of various breeds,<ref name="rassiya"/> including deerhounds, staghounds and Siberian wolfhounds, as well as smaller greyhounds and foxhounds,<ref name="lopez">''Chapter 8: Wolfing for Sport'' in Barry Lopez' ''Of Wolves and Men'', 1978 Charles Scribner's Sons, New York, USA.</ref> as they made more noise than borzoi.<ref name="rassiya"/> A beater, holding up to six dogs by leash, would enter a wooded area where wolves would have been previously sighted.<ref name="lopez"/> Other hunters on horseback would select a place in the open where the wolf or wolves may break. Each hunter held one or two borzois, which would be slipped the moment the wolf takes flight.<ref name="rassiya"/> Once the beater sighted a wolf, he would shout "Loup! Loup! Loup!" and slip the dogs. Thea idea was to trap the wolf between the pursuing dogs and the hunters on horseback outside the wood.<ref name="lopez"/> The borzois would pursue the wolf along with the horsemen and yapping curs. Once the wolf was caught by the borzois, the foremost rider would dismount and quickly dispatch the wolf with a knife. Occasionally, wolves are captured alive in order to better train borzoi pups.<ref name="rassiya">''Russia As I Know It'', by Harry De Windt, Published by BiblioBazaar, LLC, 2009, {{ISBN|1-103-19677-4}}, {{ISBN|978-1-103-19677-7}}, 272 pages</ref>
Before the [[Emancipation reform of 1861]], wolf hunting was done solely by authorised firearm holders, usually police, soldiers, rich landowners or nobles. Upon learning of the frequency of attacks on livestock and humans, the [[Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs|Czarist Ministry of the Interior]] sent agents to Western Europe in order to learn how the people there dealt with wolf problems. Upon returning, the Ministry of Internal Affairs developed a plan in 1846 to deal with wolves involving the opening of wolf bounties and appointment of government hunters. Each hunter was given jurisdiction to hunt in one district, with more than one for large areas. Hunters were given 3 [[Russian ruble|rubles]] for each male wolf killed and 1.5 for each cub, with a tail presented as proof. Each hunter would receive an annual salary of 60 rubles a year, provided he kill 15 adults and 30 cubs a year. Peasant hunters however were rarely rewarded, due to corrupt bureaucrats stealing the money. In 1858, after paying $1 250 000 for over a million wolves in Central Russia, officials became suspicious, and discovered that some hunters bought wolf pelts for low prices, cut them up and handed them to magistrates as wolf tails. In the latter years of the 19th century, Russian hunting societies began an energetic campaign against wolves. In 1897, members of the Moscow Hunting Society killed their first 1000 wolves, though the number of professional wolf hunters at the time was rather low. [[Serf]]s began hunting wolves after their emancipation in 1861, though rarely with success, as civilian firearms were highly expensive, and the cheaper ones were usually primitive and unable to bare the heavy ammunition necessary to kill wolves.<ref name="Graves">{{cite book | author=Graves, Will |url=http://www.wolvesinrussia.com/ | title=Wolves in Russia: Anxiety throughout the ages | year=2007 | page=222 | isbn=1-55059-332-3 | publisher=Detselig Enterprises | location=Calgary | accessdate=2009-11-01}}</ref> After the [[October Revolution|Russian Revolution (1917)]], the newly formed [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government worked heavily to eradicate wolves and other predators during an extensive land reclamation program.<ref name="RUSWH">{{cite web| url = http://www.wolfsongalaska.org/wolf_russia_history.html| title = ''Hunting A History of Wolves in Russia''| work = Evgeni Okhtin| publisher = Wolf Song of Alaska| accessdate = 2007-09-12| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/19991022033534/http://www.wolfsongalaska.org/wolf_russia_history.html| archivedate = 1999-10-22| df = }}</ref> During [[Eastern Front (World War II)|the Eastern Front]], wolf populations increased, though after [[Nazi Germany]]'s defeat, wolf hunts resumed. With the end of the war and the onset of aerial hunting, the USSR destroyed 42,300 wolves in 1945, 62,700 wolves in 1946, 58,700 wolves in 1947, 57,600 in 1948, and 55,300 in 1949. From 1950 to 1954, an average of 50,000 wolves were killed annually. In 1966, wolves had been successfully exterminated in 30 [[oblast]]s of the [[RSFSR]]. During this time, wolf depredations on humans and livestock had dropped by a factor of ten. However, with the publishing of a [[Russian language|Russian]] translation of [[Farley Mowatt]]'s [[fictional]] book ''[[Never Cry Wolf]]'', wolf hunts decreased in popularity. Amid public outcry, Czarist and Soviet records of wolf attacks on both livestock and people were ignored and wolf hunts decreased in number, allowing wolves to multiply. 15,900 wolves were reportedly culled from the [[RSFSR]] in 1978, compared to 7,900 two years prior. With an increase in population, twice as many wolves were culled in the 1980s than in the prior decade.<ref name="Graves" /> Wolves became extinct in [[Wrangel Island]] in the early 1980s.<ref name="Russki">{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/animals/features/284feature1.shtml | title = In defence of Russia's wolves | work = | publisher = bbc.co.uk| accessdate = 2008-04-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050406150238/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/animals/features/284feature1.shtml |archivedate=2005-04-06}}</ref> In 1984, the RSFSR had over 2000 wolf hunting brigades consisting of 15,000 hunters who killed 16 400 wolves.<ref name="Graves" /> Overall, the Soviet Union culled over 1 500 000 wolves for a cost of 150,000,000 rubles on bounties alone. With the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], many wolf bounties were lowered or dropped altogether.<ref name="Graves" /> Wolf hunting continues in Russia, at the expense of individual hunters rather than the government.<ref name="Волки">{{cite web | url = http://gazeta.aif.ru/online/aif/1102/07_02| script-title=ru:Волки: серое нашествие | work = | publisher = Аргументы и факты | accessdate = 2008-08-14|language=ru}}</ref>
==Hunting with hounds== {{further|Borzoi|West Siberian Laika}} [[File:PeterII&Elizaveta.jpg|thumb|left|''Peter II and his aunt [[Elizaveta Petrovna]] go hunting'', a 1900 painting by [[Alexandre Benois]].]] Under Grand Duke [[Vasili III of Russia|Vasili III]], who personally loved the huntings for hare, there were over one hundred chasseurs who dealt particularly with wolves and foxes.<ref name="OVR">{{cite web|last=Савченко |first=Борис |authorlink= |coauthors= |script-title=ru:Под царским прицелом |work= |publisher=Отдых в России |date= |url=http://www.rustur.ru/news/news1632.html |doi= |accessdate=2007-06-09 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070227180319/http://www.rustur.ru/news/news1632.html |archivedate=2007-02-27 |df= }}</ref> The court hunt of that time embraced the chasseurs with hounds (выжлятники), their head (доезжачий), [[borzoi]] hunters (борзятники), dog-breeders and beaters. Additionally there were cooks, grooms and drivers. Depending on the number of hounds there were big and small hunts. The first one involved forty hounds and twelve packs of three borzois each, and the second consisted of eighteen hounds and twenty borzois in five packs.<ref name="OVR"/>
The gunless hunting with hounds, particularly for hares or foxes, became widespread in the Russian Empire in the 18th-19th centuries, after the reign of [[Anna of Russia|Empress Anna]] who liked gun [[deerstalking]]. [[Peter II of Russia|Emperor Peter II]] and [[Empress Elizabeth]] were among the most prominent lovers of hunting with hounds. The longest hunt of Peter II took place in 1729 in [[Tula Oblast|Tula]], where fifty foxes, five bears, five [[lynx]]es and many hares were baited between September 7 and October 16. In that time the state kennel consisted of two hundred hounds and 420 borzois. [[Poaching]] has been fought notably by Empress Anna and [[Empress Catherine II]].
As landlords, counts and dukes had kennels, there were stables and villages with serfs, who sowed oats which was to be mixed with meat as a hound forage. Each kennel could support up to 1,000 hounds.<ref name="HOU">{{cite web|last=Соловьев |first=Евгений |authorlink= |coauthors= |script-title=ru:Охота с гончими как зеркало общественных трансформаций |work= |publisher=Независимая Газета |date= |url=http://www.hunter.ru/hunting/articles/nezavisimaja.htm |doi= |accessdate=2007-06-09 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070329212443/http://www.hunter.ru/hunting/articles/nezavisimaja.htm |archivedate=2007-03-29 |df= }}</ref> The [[Emancipation reform of 1861]] put an end to hunting with hounds. In 1917 there were only two hound chases in the fading Russian Empire: Gatchina and [[Pershino]], in the Tula Governorate.<ref name="HOU"/>
==Hunting birds== [[File:Chetverikova-Avanzo hunt.jpg|thumb|125px|Noblewomen hunting. Taken in the 1890s.]] Orthodox martyr [[Tryphon of Campsada|Saint Trifon]] is often depicted with a white [[Merlin (bird)|merlin]] on his hand. Particularly the name of [[Moscow]]'s [[Sokolniki Park]] refers to the rapid spread of [[falconry]]-related ''[[sloboda]]s'' in Tsarist Russia. As indicated by English diplomat [[Jerome Horsey]], [[Boris Godunov]] used to be a hawker. Meanwhile, the use of hunting birds was already popular among Russian nobility in the times of the [[Golden Horde]].<ref name="FALC">{{cite web | last = | first = |authorlink = | coauthors = | script-title=ru:Русский соколиный центр| work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.deol.ru/nature/falcon/| format =| doi = | accessdate = 2007-06-10|language=ru}}</ref> There were several hundred such birds in possession of Ivan IV, and even the road tax was collected in pigeons for falcons.<ref name="FALC"/> However, the first famous hawker was Alexis I, who created the falconry statute book (''Урядник сокольничья пути''). The white, red or speckled merlins were also in common usage in those days. The merlin cocks were called ''cheligi'' (челиги). The places where the birds were caught were called ''pomchishcha'' (помчища) and the catchers - ''pomytchiki'' (помытчики). Before the reign of Feodor I each ''pomytchik'' community annually delivered three living falcons to the prince's falcon loft. In the time of Feodor I it became necessary to obtain two red merlins, three speckled and thirty-five grey.
There were two state merlin lofts, in Semyonovskoye (in modern [[Sokolniki Park]]) and [[Kolomenskoye]]. An Italian ambassador, [[Horatio Calvucci]], had been trying to get in and sketch at least one bird for six months; the embassy finally gained an access on February 13, 1662. In 1805 there were only fifteen hunting birds left in Semyonovskoye. The last event with hunting birds occurred during the coronation of [[Alexander II of Russia|Alexander II]]. The [[golden eagle]]s were taken from Orenburg Governorate to hunt for wolves and foxes at that time.
==Walrus== The first mention of Russia-related [[walrus]] hunting, in the [[Arctic]] part of the [[Northern Atlantic]], is dated back to the late 9th century.<ref name="WAL">{{cite web|last=Yurchenko |first=A |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Russian walrus hunting: history of crisis in the 19th century |work= |publisher= |date= |url=http://www.vitiaz.ru/congress/en/thesis/101.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040114201801/http://vitiaz.ru/congress/en/thesis/101.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2004-01-14 |doi= |accessdate=2007-06-09 }}</ref> At that time the [[Viking]] [[Ohthere of Hålogaland]], sailing along the [[Kola Peninsula]], landed somewhere on the [[White Sea]] coast and established trade relations with aboriginal people for [[walrus ivory]].<ref name="WAL"/> The [[Slavs]] and [[Saami people]], who penetrated to this area in the early 12th century, could only hunt for small groups of walruses and came to the northern part of the White Sea from time to time.<ref name="WAL"/> The Russian walrus hunting in that region started in the early 16th century.<ref name="WAL"/> Purposeful and mass walrus hunting was stimulated by the exploration of the Arctic [[archipelago]]es [[Novaya Zemlya]] and [[Spitsbergen]] with adjacent areas where the large walrus rookeries were concentrated. The collapse of Russian walrus hunting happened at the first half of the 19th century, being a result of interaction of both [[ecology|ecological]] and [[anthropology|anthropological]] factors.<ref name="WAL"/>

The [[caste system in India]] prohibits marriage outside the caste.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Caste, Society and Politics in India from the Eighteenth Century to the Modern Age|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=HbAjKR_iHogC|publisher = Cambridge University Press|date = 2001-02-22|isbn = 9780521798426|first = Susan|last = Bayly}}</ref> However, '''inter-caste marriages''' have gradually gained acceptance due to increasing education, employment, middle-class economic background, and urbanisation. According to a survey in 2014, about 5% of marriages are inter-caste in India.
In India, inter-caste marriages were publicly encouraged and supported by politicians such as [[C. N. Annadurai]], former Chief Minister of [[Tamil Nadu]],<ref>{{Cite news|title = Love in the time of caste|url = http://www.thehindu.com/features/the-yin-thing/love-in-the-time-of-caste/article4960041.ece|newspaper = The Hindu|date = 2013-07-27|access-date = 2015-11-06|issn = 0971-751X|language = en-IN}}</ref> and social activists such as [[Periyar E. V. Ramasamy]],<ref name="Anita Diehl 1977">Anita Diehl. (1977). E. V. Ramaswami Periyar. ''A study of the influence of a personality in contemporary South India'', Scandinavian University Books: Sweden. {{ISBN|91-24-27645-6}}.</ref> [[Raghupathi Venkataratnam Naidu]]{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} and [[Manthena Venkata Raju]].{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} In the North Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, the Government offers a cash award for inter-caste couples.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-31037159 bbc.com: India: Cash reward offered for inter-caste marriages]</ref> The Supreme Court of India has also declared that inter-caste marriages are in the national interest and a unifying factor for the nation<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.lawyerscollective.org/news/archived-news-a-articles/115-inter-caste-marriages-in-national-interest-sc.html|title = Lawyer's Collective|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and there is no bar in inter-caste or inter-religion marriages in India.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://infochangeindia.org/women/judicial-interventions-and-women/love-inter-caste-marriage-and-criminal-law.html|title = Infochange India|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
There is an increasing trend among users of online matrimony sites in India to declare one's willingness to marry outside their caste.<ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/caste-no-bar-in-words-if-not-in-action/article4989269.ece thehindu.com: 'Caste no bar', in words if not in action]</ref> While the secular Government does not object to inter-caste marriage, in much of conservative society such marriages are taboo, and can result in ostracisation of not just the married couple but both families from respective communities. Inter-caste marriages can also prove troublesome for offspring who do not belong to either caste, and the difficulties in adopting cultural practices which vary from caste to caste. Conservative critics feel that inter-caste marriage leads to a loss of cultural heterogeneity and value.

'''Interaction cost''' are work, [[cost]]s, and other [[expense]]s, sometime dues to complete a task or [[interaction]]. This applies to several like: * [[Economy]]: Interaction cost of a purchase are the interaction cost of completing this task and differ in costs for customer and vendor. The way of payment may differ in [[transaction cost]] and interaction cost. Reducing it for customers can be a service of the vendor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/karriere/a-32662-3.html|title=Gradmesser für neue Marktchancen - manager magazin|work=manager magazin|access-date=2017-04-11}}</ref> Higher interaction cost might make customers decide to change the vendor.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Interaktive Wertschöpfung: Open Innovation, Individualisierung und neue Formen der Arbeitsteilung|last=Reichwald|first=Ralf|last2=Piller|first2=Frank|publisher=Springer|year=|isbn=9783834994400|location=25 July 2009|pages=171}}{{Google books|YGGsd96GC9cC|page=171}}</ref> Customers prefer to have choice about their interactions cost.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mancur Olsons Logik kollektiven Handelns|last=Pies|first=Ingo|last2=Leschke|first2=Martin|publisher=Mohr Siebeck|year=1997|isbn=9783161467677|location=|pages=44}}{{Google books|jzxk7uT5XhMC|page=44}}</ref> In [[self-checkout]], work is moved to the customer. * [[Politics]]: Specific interaction cost can be increased by law for political effort.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wirtschaftspolitik|last=Peters|first=Hans-Rudolf|publisher=Oldenbourg|year=2000|isbn=9783486255027|location=|pages=326}}{{Google books|wrfPfMU6O38C|page=326}}</ref> * [[User interface]]: In a [[computer menu]] with a [[graphical user interface]], some designs require more [[Point_and_click|clicks]] from the user in order to make a selection. With a [[Dropdown_menu|dropdown menu]], one click (or touch or hover) may reveal the hidden menu, and a second click is required to select a menu option. If the entire menu were displayed all along, as in a [[Navigation_bar|navigation bar]], only one click would be required, but the menu would occupy more screen space. [[Menu_(computing)#Sub-menus|Sub-menus]] require even more care from the user to make a desired selection.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interaction cost: Definition|trans-title=|periodical=|publisher=NN Group|url=http://www.nngroup.com/articles/interaction-cost-definition/|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2017-04-09|author=Raluca Budiu|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=2013-08-31|year=|month=|day=|language=English|pages=|quote=}}</ref>

Jules Jeptha Robertson | residence = West Monroe, Louisiana | years_active = 2012–present }} '''Marsha Kay Carroway Robertson''',Date and year of birth disputed. Sources cite December 21, 1950, others cite July 3, 1951, still others cite 1947 as her year of birth.{{cite news|last=Pantiss|first=Sonia|title=Duck Dynasty stars: Miss Kay Robertson|url=http://www.bellenews.com/?p=35804|newspaper=Belle News|date=June 5, 2013}} also known as '''Miss Kay''', is an American television personality, best known for her appearances on the [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] [[reality television|reality series]] ''[[Duck Dynasty]]''. Robertson is the wife of [[entrepreneur]] and ''Duck Dynasty'' co-star [[Phil Robertson]], and mother of ''Duck Dynasty'' personality and current [[Duck Commander]] [[CEO]] [[Willie Robertson]]. She is commonly referred to on the show as "Miss Kay". She has a passion for cooking.{{cite web|url=http://www.aetv.com/duck-dynasty/meet-family/miss-kay-robertson|title=Miss Kay Robertson – Duck Dynasty Cast|publisher=AEtv.com|accessdate=2012-06-16}}Hill, Erin (November 23, 2013) [http://www.parade.com/231229/erinhill "Duck Dynasty's Miss Kay on Her Love of Cooking and Family Values"], Parade.com; retrieved December 2, 2013. She is the author of the cookbook ''Miss Kay's Duck Commander Kitchen: Faith, Family, and Food--Bringing Our Home to Your Table''.[http://www.patriotledger.com/community/blogs/food-for-thought/x2132754352/Duck-Dynasty-cookbook "'Duck Dynasty' cookbook"], ''The Patriot Ledger'', November 16, 2013; retrieved December 2, 2013. ==Personal life== In high school, Kay was a cheerleader and a [[debutante]].[http://girlsjustwannahaveguns.com/2014/01/throwback-mrs-duck-dynasty-reveals-fascinating-pictures-teen-cheerleader-class-beauty Profile], girlsjustwannahaveguns.com; accessed November 20, 2015. Kay and Phil Robertson began dating in 1964 and married two years later.{{cite web|url=https://tv.yahoo.com/news/duck-dynasty--couples--how-they-met-234103918.html|title=How Did the 'Duck Dynasty' Couples Meet?|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=January 6, 2014|author=Woo, Kelly}} Some sources claim she was 16 at the time of her marriage, others indicate she was 17 when she gave birth to her first child, Alan.[http://dailyentertainmentnews.com/tv/kay-carroway-robertson-duck-dynasty-phil-robertsons-wife Profile], dailyentertainmentnews.com; accessed November 20, 2015. They have four sons: Alan, [[Jase Robertson|Jase]], [[Willie Robertson|Willie]], and Jep, as well as sixteen grandchildren and several great-grandchildren.{{cite web|last=Takeda|first=Allison|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/duck-dynastys-phil-robertson-miss-kay-open-up-about-pre-fame-infidelity-alcohol-issues-in-new-film-20132011|title=Duck Dynasty's Phil, Miss Kay Talk Infidelity, Alcoholism in New Film|publisher=Usmagazine.com|date=2013-11-20|accessdate=2014-01-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/duck-dynasty-stars-phil-miss-kay-how-jesus-christ-saved-their-marriage-restored-their-family-96101|title='Duck Dynasty' Stars Phil, Miss Kay: How Jesus Christ Saved Their Marriage, Restored Their Family |publisher=Christianpost.com|date=2013-05-18|accessdate=2014-01-02}} ==Bibliography== *''Miss Kay's Duck Commander Kitchen: Faith, Family, and Food – Bringing Our Home to Your Table'' (co-written with Chrys Howard). [[University of Virginia]], {{small|([[Master of Laws|L.L.M.]])}} | occupation = Aerospace engineer; attorney; judge | profession = Law | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Keith Rapp''' (also known as W. Keith Rapp) is a judge on the [[Oklahoma Court of Civil Appeals]], the intermediate appellate court in the state of [[Oklahoma]]. He represents District 2, Office 2. A native of Ohio, he earned his J.D. degree from the University of Tulsa Law School ==Biography== Judge Rapp was born on May 2, 1934 in [[Wheelersburg, Ohio]]. He received his undergraduate degree from [[Missouri State University]] and took graduate classes in mathematics and statistics from the [[University of Missouri]], [[University of Minnesota]] and [[University of Arizona]]. Rapp then worked as an [[aerospace engineer]] on many major [[N.A.S.A.]] projects before receiving his J.D. degree from the [[University of Tulsa]]. Rapp later earned a Master of Laws degree from the [[University of Virginia]].[http://okciviljustice.com/keith "Keith Rapp." Oklahoma Civil Justice Council. 2018.] Accessed May 7, 2018. ==Military service and aerospace career== From 1953 to 1955, he served in the [[US Navy]], completing two tours of duty in the Far East as an aerial navigator and electronics warfare operator with the VC-35. Later, he retired from the U.S. Naval Reserves as a Judge Advocate General Corps commander. Returning to civilian life, Rapp went to work as an aerospace engineer, specializing in inertial guidance and navigation systems. Some of his projects included Mercury, Gemini, Apollo, and SkyLab for the U.S. space program and Bomarc, the first operational surface-to-air missile for the Department of Defense. While working as an engineer, he enrolled in the University of Tulsa School of Law, where he earned his Juris Doctor (J.D.) degree. Later, he earned the LLM degree from the University of Virginia.{{efn|According to the University of Virginia alumni publication, Rapp graduated in the class of 1990.[http://www.law.virginia.edu/html/alumni/uvalawyer/sp06/90.htm "1990s Class Notes." ''UVA Lawyer''. Spring 1996.] Accessed May 7, 2018.}} ==Legal career== After completing law school at the University of Tulsa, Judge Rapp served as a [[public defender]] and [[city prosecutor]] in [[Broken Arrow, Oklahoma]]. He later served as a municipal judge in [[Bixby, Oklahoma]] and then an alternative municipal judge in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]. After this, he was judge on the 14th District Court in Tulsa. He stood for election against incumbent Judge [[Fred DeMier]] for the Oklahoma Court of Civil Appeals in 1984. It was the first time a challenger had unseated an incumbent since the Oklahoma Court of Civil Appeals was created in 1969.[http://newsok.com/article/2087547 "Court of Appeals Judge Unseated." NewsOK. November 8, 1984.] Accessed May 7, 2018.{{efn|DeMeir and Rapp had met on a ballot once before, when running against each other in 1982 for a two-year term as Civil Appeals Court Judge. DeMeir had won that match.}} Voters chose to retain Rapp on the Appeals Court most recently in the 2014 election. His retention rating was 59.3 percent. ==Personal== He married the former Mary Lynn Clanton. They have three children, Elizabeth, Kathy and Joseph. ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==External links== * [http://www.oscn.net/oscn/schome/civilappeals.htm Oklahoma Court of Civil Appeals website] * [http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?articleID=20081026_14_VO2_Ialtnh27502 Tulsa World: Court of Appeals Judges on 2008 Ballot] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rapp, Keith}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:People from Wheelersburg, Ohio]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:Missouri State University alumni]] [[Category:University of Tulsa alumni]] [[Category:University of Virginia alumni]] [[Category:Aerospace engineers]]
